qas.question: What did Charles Darwin call the sudden appearance of nearly modern flowers in the fossil record?
What type of fossil is the recently discovered Archaefructus?
What fossil evidence is lacking when it comes to flowers?

answers.text: evidence showing exactly how flowers evolved

qas.question: From what period does fossilized pollen suggest an older date for angiosperm origin?
What relationship proposed on the basis of morphological evidence has recently been disputed?
What was ancestors of angiosperms suddenly appearing called by Charles Darwin?
What have several groups of Archaefructus been proposed to be?
What is missing to show how ancestors of angiosperms diverged from an unknown group?

plausible_answers.text: on the basis of molecular evidence

qas.question: Why has the relationship between gnetophytes and gymnosperms been disputed?
What type of fossil is the recently discovered Sanmiguelia?

context: The apparently sudden appearance of nearly modern flowers in the fossil record initially posed such a problem for the theory of evolution that it was called <b5_0>an "<a0_0>abominable mystery<a0_0/>"<b5_0/> by Charles Darwin. However, the fossil record has considerably grown since the time of Darwin, and recently discovered <a1_0><b9_0>angiosperm<b9_0/><a1_0/> fossils such as Archaefructus, along with further discoveries of fossil gymnosperms, suggest how angiosperm characteristics may have been acquired in a series of steps. Several groups of extinct gymnosperms, in particular seed ferns, have been proposed as <b6_0>the ancestors of flowering plants<b6_0/>, but there is no <b7_0>continuous fossil <a2_0>evidence<b7_0/> showing exactly how flowers evolved<a2_0/>. Some older fossils, such as the upper Triassic Sanmiguelia, have been suggested. Based on current evidence, some propose that the ancestors of the angiosperms diverged from an unknown group of gymnosperms in the Triassic period (245–202 million years ago). Fossil angiosperm-like pollen from the <a3_0>Middle Triassic<a3_0/> (247.2–242.0 Ma) suggests an older date for their origin. A close <a4_0>relationship between angiosperms and gnetophytes<a4_0/>, proposed on the basis of morphological evidence, has more recently been disputed <b8_0>on the basis of molecular evidence<b8_0/> that suggest gnetophytes are instead more closely related to other gymnosperms.[citation needed]
